Description: Terracotta figure of a hedgehog (or tortoise?) rattle; handmade; modelled snout and ears, regular rows of bumps across the curved back, flat underside with four short rounded legs; two small pre-firing holes on the left-hand side; pellet inside hollow interior that rattles when shaken. Medium-coarse orange-brown clay with some mica and black inclusions, some sand (7.5YR 7/4-7/6); traces of white covering and small flecks of red and yellow paint.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallel from Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford AN1886.511). A Corinthian (?) parallel in Frankfurt Museum is dated to the early 5th century BC (Bol and Kotera 1986, 63, no. 33) and Rhodian (?) parallels from Kamiros, Rhodes (Higgins 1954, no 191 and 197; Jacopi 1930, 142, fig. 137). This is probably an Egyptian copy of an East Greek or Cypriot type. Bol, P. C., Kotera, E. 1986, Bildwerke aus Terrakotta aus mykenischer bis römischer Zeit. Liebieghaus-Museum alter Plastik Antike Bildwerke III, Melsungen. Jacopi, G. 1930. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos IV. Scavi Nelle Necropoli Camiresi 1929-1930.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.315) (Phase 1)
